title.narrative: BELARUS PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT MODERNIZATION PROJECT

description.narrative: To improve policy alignment of the budget, consolidate cash balances, improve budget transparency and lay foundations for implementation of an Integrated Financial Management Information System (FMIS)

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Implementation Arrangements Documents | Description :To facilitate carrying out of the Project, the Borrower,through MoF, shall issue a resolution and, immediately thereafter, enter into an agreement with the IT Center, all under terms andconditions acceptable to the Bank (Implementation Arrangements) which shall include, inter alia, the obligation of the IT Centerto: (i) implement the Project in accordance with the pertinent provisions of this Agreement (including compliance with thepertinent provisions set forth in the Procurement and Financial Management sections and the provisions of Article V of the GeneralConditions), the Anti-Corruption Guidelines and the POM; (ii) use the proceeds of the Loan exclusively for the purposes of theProject; (iii) promptly inform the Borrower, through MoF, and the Bank of any condition which interferes, or threatens tointerfere, with the performance of its obligations under the Implementation Arrangements; and (iv) take or permit to be taken allactions to enable the Borrower to comply with the obligations referred to in this Agreement as applicable to the IT Center. | DueDate: 30-Jun-2016

title.narrative: Increase the level of consolidation of cash balances (by reducing balances outside of TSA)
Improved alignment of policies and budgets

baseline.value: Citizens budget has not been prepared.

target.value: Citizens budget is published online on annual basis and includes information on budget execution disaggregated at the level ofapproved budget;information on medium term financial program; and analysis of links between financing and results. Citizens’questions and feedback are published onthe website along with responses of the MoF to frequently asked questions.

actual.value: Citizens’ budget is published online on annual basis and includes information on budget execution disaggregated at the level ofapproved budget; information on medium term financial program; and analysis of links between financing and results. Citizens’questions and feedback are published on the website along with responses of the MoF to frequently asked questions.

baseline.value: Future business processes to be supported by FMIS are not fully defined.

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be partially achieved. The MoF and the IT Center had decided to proceed with reengineering of thePFM business-process, design and development (upgrade) of the new system’s modules, using their own resources (ongoing). As ofproject closing: (i) new business processes for the revenue management subsystem were finalized and development of the softwarestarted; (ii) business processes for budget execution subsystem are nearly completed; (iii) methodological frameworks for twosubsystems (debt management and staff and payroll management) have been prepared and the work on the current and future businessprocesses have been started.

baseline.value: Future business processes to be supported by IFMIS are not fully defined.

target.value: Bidding documents for FMIS are prepared based on approved revised business processes and Unified Chart of Accounts and cover thefollowing functionality including planning, execution, financial control, accounting and reporting, debt management.

actual.value: This indicator is deemed partially achieved. After the cancellation of the IFMIS design consultancy in September 2020, the MoF andIT Center have decided to proceed with in-house development of a new modular-based system using, mainly, their own budgetresources.This decision implied that the bidding documents, considered in the original end target of this indicator, were no longerapplicable. As of the project closing date, the following results have been achieved: (i) the new Unified Chart of Accounts hasbeen already developed and approved; (ii) existing MoF’s systems and ICT infrastructure have been considerably improved; (iii)IFMIS implementation roadmap has been prepared and is being regularly updated; (iv) new business processes for the revenuemanagement subsystem were finalized and development of the software started; (v) new business processes for budget executionsubsystem are nearly completed, (vi) “as is” business processes for the following three subsystems (budget planning, an

title.narrative: Integration of budget and financial reporting based on international standards (Text, Custom)

baseline.value: Methodological basis for public sector financial and budget reporting has not been integrated and deviates from applicableinternational standards.

target.value: Unified Chart of Accounts integratedwith the budget classification andguidelines for its application areapproved.

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be fully achieved. The UCoA and the methodology for its piloting were approved by Order of the MoFN392 dated November 29, 2019. The approved UCoA informed the requirements for the dedicated software developed by the IT Center topilot the UCoA in several types of the spending units during CY21. UCoAs and supporting instructions will be further revisedfollowing results of the pilot in CY22.

baseline.value: Program budgeting methodology does not clearly link objectives and resources.

target.value: Program budgeting methodology isapproved, allows looking at differentsocial dimensions, including gender, inselected relevantprograms.

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be partially achieved. Selected improvements of the program budgeting methodology had beenimplemented in the new cycle of state programs covering CY21-25. Further amendments to the methodology for development, financing,and execution of state programs (President’s Edict N289 from July 25, 2016) had been prepared by the government, but its approvalis still pending.

title.narrative: Conceptual framework for public sector accounting reform

baseline.value: Public sector accounting reform is defined as a priority in PFM Strategy, but the reform direction is not defined.

target.value: Public sector accounting reformimplementation launched by finalizing development of first 3-4 accounting standards compliant withIPSAS

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be fully achieved and exceeded. The concept for modernization national PSA and reporting as well asthe initial plan for its implementation were approved by the Government on February 9, 2019. The Treasury prepared the five firstnew national PSA standards, which are aligned with the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS).

title.narrative: Reliability and fault tolerance of the ASFS

baseline.value: The ASFS at the republican level operates at two geographically distant sites. There is no full-fledged backup system; there is ahigh probability of data loss in the event of an accident. Domain and postal structures of the ASFS are scattered. The ITinfrastructure at the Oblast level is outdated. It is not possible to deploy a fault-tolerant cluster (FTC) allowing for controlof computing resources using the new equipment

target.value: A uniform distribution of the load on the ASFS and efficient data processing and backup through "Active-Active" geographicallydistributed cluster. Modern IT infrastructure with server virtualization software and virtualization management centers isestablished at the republican and oblast levels (12 sites) including virtual machines control center and capabilities to deploy afault-tolerant cluster (FTC)

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be partially achieved (full achievement expected by the end of CY21). A geographically distributedcluster has been built in the central office of the MoF, operating in the "Active-Active" mode (hereinafter referred to as theCluster). Conditions created to ensure the ASFS operation at the republican level with a high level of fault tolerance andreliability, with an even distribution of the ASFS load. Transfer of the ASFS modules to the Cluster is ongoing. The virtualinfrastructure is currently being deployed on new equipment, which was purchased by the MoF, using their own funds, in 2020.Installation and configuration of the new equipment will be completed by the IT Center in 2021. This will allow to: (i) establishFTC; and (ii) create an ability to manage virtual machines and control computing resources.

baseline.value: There is no centralized storage of the ASFS databases for planning and execution of local budgets. It is not possible to operatethe ASFS segment in emergency (abnormal) mode using the backup equipment

target.value: Centralized storage of databases of MoF territorial bodies and local finance bodies at MoF is ensured through high-speed andreliable data storage system. The capability to operate the ASFS in emergency (abnormal) mode using the backup equipment is ensured

actual.value: This indicator is considered to be partially achieved (full achievement expected in CY22).Collection and centralized storage ofdatabases of territorial bodies of the MoF and local financial bodies are ensured using high-speed and reliable data storagesystem. This system also improves the safety of databases and the operability of the main ASFS modules in the event of a failure ofany part of the ASFS soft- or hardware infrastructure.According to the order of the MoF N23, dated January 26, 2021, thecapability to operate the ASFS in emergency (abnormal) mode using the backup equipment will be enabled upon introduction ofautomatic data bases back-up, as follows: (i) by November 30, 2021 for the central apparatus of the MoF; and (ii) by June 30, 2022for the territorial bodies of the MoF and local finance bodies.
